The battery is chiefly responsible for firing ceremonial cannon volleys on state occasions and for providing artillery support to the regiment during combat operations in defense of [[Washington, D.C]]. ==History== Activated in 1953, the Presidential Salute Battery is equipped with ten [[3-inch Gun M5]]s which have been mounted on [[M6 howitzer]] carriages. The M5 is a World War II-era weapon.{{cite web|title=Presidential Salute Battery|url=http://www.oldguard.mdw.army.mil/specialty-platoons/psb|website=mdw.army.mil|publisher=[[U.S. Army]]|accessdate=26 April 2016}}{{cite book|last1=Michael|first1=John|title=Fort Myer|date=2011|publisher=Arcadia|isbn=1439642346|page=127|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0pwJAwAAQBAJ&dq=}} [[File:U.S. Soldiers with the Presidential Salute Battery, 3rd U.S. Infantry Regiment (The Old Guard) fire cannons during a training exercise at Arlington National Cemetery, Va 130115-A-MM054-036.jpg|thumb|left|The Presidential Salute Battery pictured in 2013 during a training exercise at Arlington National Cemetery.]] The battery renders gun salutes according to a customary order of arms which is 21 volleys for heads of state (including the president of the United States and former presidents); 19 for the [[vice-president of the United States]], foreign [[chief of government|chiefs of government]], and members of the [[cabinet of the United States]]; and 17, 15, 13, and 11 for [[flag officers]] of the rank of [[U.S. uniformed services pay grades|O-10, O-9, O-8, and O-7]], respectively.{{cite book|title=FM 3–21.5 "Drill and Ceremonies"|date=2003|publisher=[[U.S. Army]]}} Under an 1890 regulation issued by the [[United States Department of War]], the "Salute to the Union" consists of one round for every [[U.S. state|state of the United States]], or 50 rounds since 1959; it is fired by the battery annually at noon on U.S. Independence Day.{{cite news|title=Expect to Hear Booms from 50-Gun Salute Tomorrow|url=http://wtop.com/news/2012/07/expect-to-hear-booms-from-50-gun-salute-tomorrow/|accessdate=26 April 2016|work=[[WTOP-AM]]|date=3 July 2012}}{{cite web|title=Origin of the 21-Gun Salute|url=http://www.history.army.mil/html/faq/salute.html|website=history.army.mil|publisher=[[U.S. Army Center of Military History]]|accessdate=26 April 2016}} During ceremonial volleys, the Presidential Salute Battery fires blank artillery rounds packed with a 1.5 pound powder charge.{{cite news|title=Presidential Salute Battery Practice|url=http://www.military.com/video/guns/artillery/presidential-salute-battery-practice/3751475318001|accessdate=26 April 2016|work=[[military.com]]|date=27 August 2014}} ==Mission== ===Funerals=== The battery is customarily deployed to [[Arlington National Cemetery]] for the [[State funerals in the United States|funerals of sitting and former presidents of the United States]], sitting cabinet secretaries, and military [[flag officer]]s.{{cite web|title=Full Military Honors|url=http://www.arlingtoncemetery.mil/Funerals/About-Funerals/Military-Honors/Full|website=arlingtoncemetery.mil|publisher=[[Arlington National Cemetery]]|accessdate=26 April 2016}} For funerals at Arlington it uses one of two firing positions, either from Section 4 of the cemetery on Dewey Drive, or at Red Springs on McClellan Drive.{{cite book|last1=Knudsen|first1=Robert|title=A Living Treasure: Seasonal Photographs of Arlington National Cemetery|date=2008|publisher=Potomac Books|isbn=159797272X|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yxf9Dyds86kC&pg=PT185&dq=%22#v=onepage&q&f=false}} ===Public and military observances=== The battery fires ceremonial gun salutes at events including the U.S. Army's weekly [[military tattoo|Twilight Tattoo]], observances for [[Flag Day (United States)|Flag Day]] and Independence Day, and at the inauguration of a new president of the United States.{{cite web|last1=Leipold|first1=JD|title=Twilight Tattoo marks 238 years of Army history|url=http://www.army.mil/article/105547/Twilight_Tattoo_marks_238_years_of_Army_history/|website=army.mil|publisher=[[U.S. Army]]|accessdate=26 April 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Vigeant|first1=Fred|title=A Capitol Fourth Celebration|url=http://www.witf.org/on-air/2015/06/-celebrating-35-spectacular-years.php|accessdate=26 April 2016|work=[[WITF-TV]]|date=17 June 2015}}{{cite news|title=On Flag Day, U.S. Army Celebrates 238th Birthday|url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2013/06/14/flag-day-us-army-celebrates-238th-birthday-149902|accessdate=26 April 2016|work=Indian Country Media Network|date=14 June 2013}}{{cite web|last1=Vinyard|first1=Erica|title=Always heard but never seen|url=http://www.army.mil/article/56825/Always_heard_but_never_seen/|website=army.mil|publisher=[[U.S. Army]]|accessdate=26 April 2016}}{{cite book|last1=Levy|first1=Leonard|title=Encyclopedia of the American Presidency, Volume 4|date=1994|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=0132759756|page=1348|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kVc_AYJ0qBQC&q}} [[File:Mortar3rdIR.png|thumb|right|Presidential Salute Battery soldiers train on the M252 mortar in 2013, their primary equipment for non-ceremonial duties.]] ===Military operations=== In support of the 3rd Infantry Regiment's non-ceremonial responsibilities, primarily the military defense of the city of Washington, platoon members operate the 81mm [[M252]] mortar which would be used to provide indirect fire support to the regiment in repelling an enemy from the capital.{{cite web|last1=Ballentine|first1=Chris|title=Presidential Salute Battery Conducts Mortar Live Fire|url=http://www.army.mil/article/112874/Presidential_Salute_Battery_Conducts_Mortar_Live_Fire/|website=army.mil|publisher=[[U.S. Army]]|accessdate=26 April 2016}} ===State and official visits=== During the [[State Arrival Ceremony|White House arrival ceremony at state and official visits]], the battery fires cannon volleys from a firing position in [[President's Park]] during the performance of the visiting state's [[national anthem]].{{cite book|last1=French|first1=Mary Mel|title=United States Protocol|date=2010|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield}} ==See also== * [[21-gun salute]]
